Transcription for 961966

I left school at 14, I went to a primary school, secondary modern school in Markham.
I left school at 15 years of age, I was 15 in September and I started in the mines in 1962,
and I started in the mines Christmas Eve of the same year.
I started underground, did my training, went to college, did some training,
and then I went to work on the face with some men. Within a year I broke my foot.
I was still only, I think perhaps just coming up to 16 or 16.
How did you break your foot?
I was what they call withdrawing, getting timbers out,
whole timbers out that had been supported in the roof and letting it go out.
I cut this one up with an axe and actually the stone fell and it rolled over and it went over main step,
it went straight over my steel choke up and into my main step.
The funny thing about it was that they took me straight to my house in the ambulance,
called my mother and said, do you want to see him before we take him out?
I was frightened to death. Yeah, they did that.
Then I came back, I worked on the face for a while and then I was asked to go to work with the splices.
So I went to work with the splices and I worked with the splices for about two years.
I was a striker, when they were cutting steel ropes I was the guy with the armour, the sledge.
While doing that, a piece of steel went up through my eye and I was in hospital again and I was still only young.
They took me, the eye was alright, they saved the eye, everything was okay.
The thing about that was that they took, as soon as I did it,
they sent goggles down the mine for everybody who was using anything that afternoon, everything went alright.
So I did that and then that was okay.
I worked for a few years in the mines and decided that I'd go out to the mine site.
I was in roads working and repairing and on the coal.
Then I went outside to work and I worked for Wyn's Heavy Aldridge in Newport, massive company, big, carried heavy stuff.
I was a stiersman, finished there, went to work in a foundry and I thought, no I don't like this, I'm going back to the mines.
So I went back into the mines, went to Markham, Colleray and was a repairer and I worked on a coal.
Then the manager came to see me one day and said, I heard you were with the ventilation officers in Auckland when you were training.
I said, yeah, I'd like to train to be a ventilation officer here.
So I did and I went and I passed the exams and everything and I think they were pretty good and I worked on doing that.
Then my marriage broke up after a couple of years and the manager stopped my lamp one day and said to me,
listen Glen, there's a place in the Rhondda, in Dinas, in the mines rescuization, full time.
If you're interested in going, I'll put your name forward.
So I did and that's where I went to and I was there for about 10 years and then I had an accident with my leg, not underground or anything,
but I hurt my foot and somebody came to see me and it wasn't fair to go down there, then a problem with walking.
If I had to carry somebody, I would be a liability in case something went wrong.
So I decided it was time to go out.
So then they came and they offered me redundancy and I took the redundancy and went outside.
Since then I've started up my own business and I'm still working today.
Did you enjoy working in the mines?
Loved it, absolutely loved it.
It was hard work and it was dangerous work, but I like to come regularly.
I've been around everywhere and there is nowhere that I have seen a camaraderie like that.
I would imagine the only thing near that would be a soldier.
I wouldn't think anybody, I've never seen it anywhere else.
It was kind of you were all in the same position.
We were all in the same position and if somebody, if he was working in the face and somebody had a piece of rough ground, it was bad,
then you would finish your work and go and help him and the other blokes would come and help him and make it good.
He was watching out for one another all the time.
That was the thing. It was good.
They looked out for you and that was good.
I really enjoyed that camaraderie.
Proper teamwork as well.
Yes, it was. It was always teamwork.
Were you taught teamwork? Was it just a natural thing?
It was a natural thing, I think, that it just carried on.
I went to work in the foundry and this is why I finished in the foundry, was that sometimes it was aluminium we were using
and sometimes you put an ingot in and if there was water or it was cold, he would explore and go up in the air.
So everybody would run and whatever.
I went up one day and some of this molten aluminium spurted over and went down into his boots.
Nobody, but nobody, stopped working and just kept on and he was screaming on the floor.
My brother was doing brass and I was doing aluminium. Only me and him ran two miners.
I put my notes in the afternoon and my brother and we both finished. I said, I don't know what you would be like that.
There was no camaraderie at all and I was in Cavalier and I never forget that.
I really finished me towards that. I finished that day.
So there was no looking out for each other?
Not at all.
Were in the mines?
Yes, in the mines. If somebody got injured, they were on a stretcher and they were taken out.
People were there and they were always reassuring them.
Was it always in the back of your mind that you could get injured any day or was it good knowing that you did get injured?
Every miner knows every day. He's always looking out for things you knew it was instinctive to know that there was danger there all of the time.
If it wasn't the roof, it could be a journey coming or it could be a walker moving.
There were many, many different things underground that could catch you out.
But I think miners were quite vulnerable. Although we did get caught out, we did get killed and were some people.
There were some of these things.

I was just on the sick end.

Yes, I got paid until my foot was okay and then I went back to work.
You were able to go back down in the sick end.

I'll never forget it. I said, no.

Fifteen-year-old is a child, because you were a child at that time.
That was the way it was. It was okay after. I had compensation. We used to get compensation.

So you had sick pay?
Sick pay and everything like that. They paid me. I went back to work and that was it. That was the way it was.
How long were you off?
Oh, you know, approximately a month.
And they paid you full wage or was it a lesser wage?
They paid me full wage.
They paid me full my year.

Was it simply your accident?
Well, the goggles must have been there. They must have been in the colliery because they were straight down the mine.

It didn't matter, but that was the way it went.
But you had compensation. Did you have lasting damage in your eye or did it leave you right?
No, no, no. It hasn't affected my eyesight at all. They were worried about cataracts, but I never even had a cataract.
But it was the steel span and the corneas of the eye, the covering of the eye, and spread it, but it stayed there.
So they had to turn it and pull it back out. Yeah, not nice.
But yeah, they did that and they put two stitches in it. As you can see if you look, they put two stitches in my eye.
And then after a couple of weeks, they said to me, you're going to go on with your eye, you need stitches out.
So I went down to the theatre and I drew the stitches out and that's the worst pain I've ever had in my life.
I passed out about three times. They just picked it off with a tweezers and pulled it, but it was pulling it off, you know.
Pulling it out through the eye. So that wasn't nice, but yeah, I passed it about three times. I don't remember that.
